comments:
Debugging a simple HelloWorld program with no breakpoints in my target, I got
the following error in my host console:

Internal error logged from Debug UI: 
java.io.IOException
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.StreamsProxy.write(StreamsProxy.java:79)
	at
org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument.fireDocumentChanged(ConsoleDocument.java:95)
	at org.eclipse.jface.text.AbstractDocument.replace(AbstractDocument.java:777)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument.replace0(ConsoleDocument.java:132)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument$3.run(ConsoleDocument.java:192)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:29)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:93)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:1505)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1386)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:775)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:758)

	at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:820)
	at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:285)
	at SlimLauncher.main(SlimLauncher.java:14)
*** Bug 6023 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The console document is attempting to write to the proxy after it is closed 
(both the proxy and the console document).  Fixed to not write to the proxy if 
the console doc is closed.
Fixed in ConsoleDocument#fireDocumentChanged(DocumentEvent).

Please verify.
Note the easiest way I found to reproduce this problem was to run the 
DeferredBreakpoint tests on J9.

I still get this problem. Current stack trace:

Log: Thu Dec 13 16:31:57 CST 2001
4 org.eclipse.debug.ui 120 Internal error logged from Debug UI: 
java.io.IOException
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.StreamsProxy.write(StreamsProxy.java:79)
	at
org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument.fireDocumentChanged(ConsoleDocument.java:103)
	at org.eclipse.jface.text.AbstractDocument.replace(AbstractDocument.java:777)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument.replace0(ConsoleDocument.java:143)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.ConsoleDocument$3.run(ConsoleDocument.java:209)
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:29)
	at
org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java(Compiled
Code))
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java(Compiled Code))
	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java(Compiled Code))
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java(Compiled Code))
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:758)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:820)
	at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:285)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:151)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:502)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:362)

I added one more check to not report the error if the document is now closed.
Really this is a timing issue...the error is internal and with the proxy closed 
the really is nothing further that we can do.
Please verify...even though it is likely you will still see the internal log.

Verified.

I also moved the setting of fClosed to the top of ConsoleDocument#close() to
further increase the chance of the isClosed() check helping us.

Please verify this addition.
